intro: Papaver hispidum, commonly known as the hispid poppy, is a species of flowering plant in the family Papaveraceae. It is native to the mountainous regions of Central Asia and is characterized by its striking, cup-shaped flowers that range in color from red to orange. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 centimeters and features hairy stems and leaves, which give it its common name. Its flowers bloom in late summer, producing a showy display that attracts pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Papaver hispidum is often cultivated for its ornamental value in gardens and has been used in traditional medicine in some regions.
